I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The knowledge and support technical assistance (TA) is a corporate priority TA that will 
support the developing member countries (DMCs) of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) to (i) 
enhance collaboration and knowledge sharing on domestic resource mobilization (DRM) and 
international tax cooperation (ITC), in partnership with other development partners; and (ii) 
strengthen the establishment and implementation of differentiated, country-specific goals on DRM 
and ITC.1 This will be achieved through the establishment of an effective and inclusive regional 
hub on DRM and ITC, where all DMCs and development partners collaborate closely to promote 
DRM and ITC in Asia and the Pacific.2 The TA project’s key outputs are to (i) establish a regional 
hub secretariat function in ADB; (ii) promote strategic dialogues and information sharing among 
DMCs, development partners, and ADB including by organizing high-level regional conferences; 
(iii) develop a web portal for the regional hub; and (iv) drive digital solutions on DRM and ITC. 
The secretariat—initially to operate virtually—will maximize internal resources in coordination with 
relevant departments through promoting a One ADB approach, to strengthen ADB’s engagement 
and  support  for  improving  DRM  and  ITC  across  ADB.  The  TA  builds  on  the  initial 
accomplishments  of  the  TA  for  Enhancing  Tax  Transparency  of  ADB  Developing  Member 
Countries.3 
 
2.  The TA supports ADB’s Strategy 2030 operational plans for operational priority (OP) 2 on 
accelerating  progress  in  gender  equality,  OP  4  on  making  cities  more  livable,  OP  6  on 
strengthening governance and institutional capacity, and OP 7 on fostering regional cooperation 
and integration.4 The TA was endorsed during the corporate priority framework meeting in 
November 2020 and is included in the 2021 ADB Management-approved results-based work plan 
of the Sustainable Development and Climate Change Department (SDCC). It is also aligned with 
ADB’s  Anticorruption  Policy 5  in  supporting  efficient,  accountable,  and  transparent  public 
administration as part of its broader work on good governance and capacity building.6 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
3.  ADB’s Strategy 2030 recognizes the importance of revenue mobilization through OP 6 on 
strengthening governance and institutional capacity (footnote 4), and the Anticorruption Policy on 
Enhancing the Role of the Asian Development Bank in Relation to Tax Integrity.7 Given ADB’s 
long-standing experience and partnership with DMCs and development partners across Asia and 
the Pacific8 and strong convening power, ADB will further enhance its efforts on DRM and ITC as

one  of  the  keys  to  enhancing  successful  achievement  by  its  DMCs  of  the  Sustainable 
Development Goals (SDGs) in a world reshaped by the coronavirus disease (COVID-19).9 
 
4.  In 2020, the COVID-19 pandemic has caused a multidimensional health and economic 
crisis. With only a decade left to achieve the SDGs, the pandemic threatens to reverse years of 
progress.10 Before the pandemic, the financing gap11 for developing countries worldwide to 
achieve the SDGs was estimated at $2.5 trillion–$3.0 trillion annually.12 The Economic and Social 
Survey of the United Nations Economic and Social Commission for Asia and the Pacific found 
that developing countries in Asia and the Pacific would need $1.5 trillion annually to end extreme 
poverty  and  ambitiously  move  toward  universal  health  coverage,  quality  education,  and 
infrastructure while staying on track to limit climate change.13 However this amount will likely 
increase because of the impact of COVID-19. While the role of external finance is crucial in filling 
the  fiscal  gaps  of  DMCs,  strengthening  DRM  is  key.  DMC  tax  yields  have  not  increased 
concomitantly  with  the  strong  and  steady  growth  in  gross  domestic  product  over  the  last 
decades.14 Even prior to the pandemic, many DMCs did not achieve a tax yield of 15% of gross 
domestic  product—now  widely  regarded  as  the  minimum  level  required  for  sustainable 
development—because of a narrow tax base and low tax administration capacity in general.15 For 
countries to finance their SDGs, and to promote medium-term fiscal sustainability, greater effort 
in increasing tax revenues will be required. This TA will be specifically aligned to SDG 17 
(Strengthen the means of implementation and revitalize the global partnership for sustainable 
development) (footnote 9). 
 
5.  ADB’s DMCs can only achieve the SDGs if they develop and implement an ambitious 
program to mobilize substantial additional financial resources. Many governments will have to 
carefully consider their next steps in economic and public policy reform, in particular, on how to 
transition their government budgets from pandemic relief to recovery and, eventually, to providing 
their  citizens  with  more  equitable,  sustainable,  and  reliable  access  to  essential  services. 
Increased mobilization of domestic resources would not only reduce the need to issue domestic 
debt but also address possible overreliance on external debt, which may undermine the use of 
fiscal and monetary policy to support domestic economies. In developing the program to mobilize 
substantial additional revenue, the following reforms will be critical: (i) broadening the domestic 
tax base, (ii) enhancing tax compliance, and (iii) developing more transparent and efficient tax 
administration with digital technologies. It will also require ensuring that tax policy promotes 
investment,  and  that  private  sector  development  leads  to  more  inclusive  and  sustainable 
economic growth, including the SDGs. The tax policy measures, such as environmental taxes,

may be leveraged to recover the strong growth trajectory and to get development goals, including 
SDGs and green recovery, on track. Lessons from previous TA projects point to strengthening 
capacity in revenue administrations.16 This will take on added importance in light of emerging 
challenges, including significant and rapid changes in the business environment (i.e., expansion 
of cross-border supply chains and the digital economy) and the scaling up of capacity-building 
initiatives. 
 
6.  To broaden the tax base and mitigate income inequality, DMCs should consider expanding 
the tax  net  in  a manner that  encourages trust  among  its citizens,  while  adopting  a more 
progressive tax system may be a possible solution for addressing income inequality. This also 
means that governments should take decisive steps to address harmful tax practices, such as (i) 
aggressive tax planning of some multinational enterprises that exploit gaps in the interaction of 
different tax systems to artificially reduce taxable income derived from DMCs, a process known 
as base erosion and profit shifting (BEPS); and (ii) tax evasion, which happens through the 
exploitation of the interconnected global financial network and use of tax havens.17 Joining the 
Inclusive  Framework  on  BEPS  and  the  Global  Forum  on  Transparency  and  Exchange  of 
Information for Tax Purposes18 is a key step towards protecting national revenue against BEPS 
and  strengthening  DRM  through  the  implementation  of  international  standards  on  global 
transparency and exchange of information for tax purposes.19 In addition, DMCs should engage 
with the international community to address tax challenges arising from the digital transformation 
of the global economy, which are increasing as a result of the impact of COVID-19. Indeed, the 
loss of potential revenues because of a lack of a global agreement on the tax challenges arising 
from the digitalization of the economy are estimated at $50 billion–$80 billion per year.20 Given 
the narrower tax base, the loss of revenue from a no-agreement scenario is proportionately 
greater for developing and emerging economies. 
 
7.  Subsequent economic and public policy reforms should be informed both by international 
standards on transparency and exchange of information for tax purposes, as well as by country-
level development and fiscal needs, revenue administration, and tax and governance structures. 
The country-specific, medium-term revenue strategy (MTRS)21 is a mechanism for countries to 
determine a comprehensive, whole-of-government strategy for increasing tax revenues over the 
medium  term.  Complemented  by  a  communication  plan,  an  MTRS  can  help  DMCs  attain 
sustainable and effective tax system reforms. MTRSs will require high-level political support over 
an extended period, with the revenue goals being aligned with political economy considerations. 
MTRSs can also serve as foundations for development coordination. To this end, DMCs, in 
collaboration with development partners, need to maximize regional and international resources 
of knowledge, expertise, and finance on DRM and ITC. A significant gap in DRM and ITC in Asia 
and the Pacific is the lack of a pan-regional tax community.22 Although there are important tax 
communities in Asia and the Pacific, such as the Study Group on Asian Tax Administration and 
Research and the Pacific Islands Tax Administrators Association, they do not provide a platform

announced the creation of a regional hub on DRM and ITC (footnote 2), which will serve multiple 
functions, including an open, inclusive, and pan-regional tax platform for (i) strategic dialogue, 
institutional and capacity development, and exchange of information and ideas among DMCs; (ii) 
knowledge sharing across knowledge partners, international finance institutions, other bilateral 
revenue organizations, and DMCs; and (iii) collaboration and development coordination across 
development partners (footnote 2). The regional hub will promote the SDGs and the Group of 
Twenty  (G20)  and/or  Organisation  for  Economic  Co-operation  and  Development  (OECD) 
initiatives, such as the Global Forum on Transparency and Exchange of Information for Tax 
Purposes and the Inclusive Framework on BEPS (footnotes 17 and 18). The hub will also assist 
each DMC to define differentiated DRM and ITC goals, including (i) an MTRS, in coordination with 
the Platform for Collaboration on Tax;24 and (ii) a road map for digitalization of tax administrations, 
which facilitates the introduction of digital tools. 
 
8.  Development partner coordination. ADB works closely with development partners in 
strengthening taxation across Asia and the Pacific and, over time, development partners have 
each developed a specific expertise.25 The OECD leads the dialogue among the G20 and 
industrialized nations on (i) international standards to combat BEPS, (ii) global tax transparency 
and exchange of information for tax purposes, and (iii) the implications of the digital economy for 
international  taxation.  The  International  Monetary  Fund  advises  and  supports  countries  in 
achieving  overall  macroeconomic,  financial,  and  fiscal  stability,  and  provides  support  to 
strengthen fiscal and debt management with a focus on tax policy reforms. Like ADB, the World 
Bank provides capacity development and financial support for tax policy and administration 
reforms, with a focus on the adoption of international good practice. ADB is also collaborating with 
the tax communities that serve tax administrations in Asia and the Pacific mentioned in para. 7. 
A stock take of the planned activities will be conducted more effectively under the regional hub. 
 
9.  ADB experience and value addition. Given the long-standing experience, partnership, 
and convening power with DMCs across Asia and the Pacific, ADB is in a unique position to 
promote DRM and ITC and lead the regional hub through close collaboration with the finance and 
tax authorities of its DMCs and development partners. Within ADB, the Governance Thematic 
Group (SDTC-GOV) under the SDCC leads the work for promoting DRM, while the Office of 
Anticorruption and Integrity (OAI) leads the promotion of ITC. ADB’s operations departments also 
provide  important  contributions  to  strengthening  DRM  across  policy-based  lending,  project 
lending, and TA projects.  
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
10.  The TA is aligned with the following impact: DRM and ITC for supporting SDGs and 
sustaining economic recovery from COVID-19 improved (footnote 4). The TA will have the 
following outcome: collaboration and knowledge sharing on DRM and ITC enhanced.26 To confirm

Administrators Association.

progress against the TA project’s expected outcome, the regional hub secretariat will conduct 
follow-up surveys among participating DMC officials and regularly submit progress reports. These 
data sources will validate whether (i) at least 15 DMCs confirm participation in the regional hub 
activities on collaboration and knowledge sharing on DRM and ITC, and (ii) at least seven DMCs 
are implementing differentiated DRM and ITC goals appropriate for their specific circumstances 
and level of development. The goals encompass any forms of strategy or targets on DRM and 
ITC, such as an MTRS and a plan for digitalization of tax administrations. 
 
B.  Outputs, Methods, and Activities 
 
11.  Output 1: Regional hub on domestic resource mobilization and international tax 
cooperation established and institutionalized. The TA will complete the establishment of a 
dedicated and fully functional regional hub27 covering all the DMCs by expanding the initial work 
undertaken under the TA for Enhancing Tax Transparency of ADB Developing Member Countries 
(footnote 3) to create the secretariat.28 The secretariat’s functions include (i) managing high-level 
regional conferences that will bring together policy makers and practitioners from both tax policy 
and tax administration agencies to have a strategic dialogue on critical reforms in the areas of 
DRM and ITC, (ii) organizing capacity-building activities to enhance the institutional capacity of 
DMCs, and (iii) creating synergies for supporting DRM and ITC through active coordination among 
development partners and DMCs. The secretariat will also develop awareness of the value and 
importance of the regional hub to stakeholders. To this end, it will (i) create and coordinate an 
ADB communication strategy to support country initiatives to disseminate the importance of 
strengthening DRM and ITC and (ii) produce a generic communication strategy for DMCs to adopt 
and adapt to their specific needs. The secretariat will also maximize internal resources in 
coordination with relevant departments through promoting a One ADB approach, to strengthen 
ADB’s engagement and support for improving DRM and ITC across ADB. It will share internal 
and external knowledge and expertise that will help ADB operationalize DRM and ITC work that 
encompasses  development  of  the  country-specific  MTRSs,  including  through  a  regional 
workshop.29 In coordination with SDTC-GOV, OAI and regional departments, the secretariat will 
provide DMCs with technical advice on DRM and ITC concerns. 
 
12.  Output  2:  Strategic  conferences  and  dialogues  among  developing  member 
countries, development partners, and Asian Development Bank facilitated. In addition to the 
secretariat managing the high-level regional conferences, the TA will also finance DMCs to 
participate in the initial three high-level regional conferences on DRM and ITC in Asia and the 
Pacific, as described in output 1. The TA will also support strategic dialogues and policy-setting 
activities to ensure the highest impact on DRM and ITC with DMCs and development partners. 
 
13.  Output 3: Web portal on the regional hub developed. The TA will develop a web portal 
for the regional hub that will serve as a digital platform to facilitate knowledge sharing and capacity 
building on DRM and ITC. All information and learning resources developed under the regional 
hub will be shared through the portal, which will be developed within the ADB website and 
managed by the regional hub secretariat. The following main components are proposed for the 
structure of the web portal in the initial stage: (i) overview of the regional hub on DRM and ITC’s 
main features; (ii) regional hub on DRM and ITC’s background information; (iii) information on the

14.  Output 4: Digital solutions on domestic resource mobilization and international tax 
cooperation promoted. The TA will drive digital solutions on DRM and ITC by facilitating the 
digital transformation of tax administrations in selected DMCs. Toward this end, the TA will (i) 
conduct needs assessments of the digital transformation in DMCs and develop recommendations, 
which will support DMCs to develop and adopt a road map for digital transformation; and (ii) 
organize regional capacity-building and knowledge workshops that improve knowledge and 
understanding of digital transformation of tax administration (footnote 29). 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
15.  The TA is estimated to cost $2,500,000, of which (i) $2,000,000 will be financed on a grant 
basis by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund ($1,500,000 from TASF-7 and $500,000 from 
TASF-other sources), and (ii) $500,000 will be financed on a grant basis by the Republic of Korea 
e-Asia and Knowledge Partnership Fund and administered by ADB. The key expenditure items 
are listed in Appendix 2. The Republic of Korea e-Asia and Knowledge Partnership Fund will 
support (i) concept development of potential ADB projects by enhancing readiness and capacity 
building, policy advice and dialogue, and prefeasibility studies; (ii) preparation of ADB projects 
through feasibility studies; (iii) policy reform and institutional capacity building; (iv) studies, 
research,  and  analytical  work;  (v)  dissemination,  networking,  and  cross-learning;  and  (vi) 
innovative approaches promoting high-level technologies and information and communications 
technologies. It will not be used for civil works, procuring large-scale equipment, permanent 
staffing costs, or hiring staff consultants unless otherwise agreed between the Government of the 
Republic of Korea and ADB. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
16.  ADB will administer the TA. OAI and SDTC-GOV will jointly select, supervise, and evaluate 
consultants; organize workshops; and provide staff to act as resource persons in the workshops. 
The TA will be coordinated with existing TA projects on DRM and ITC and Domestic Resource 
Mobilization Trust Fund initiatives to maximize the potential benefits that DMCs can gain with 
respect to DRM and ITC. It will be implemented in collaboration with regional and other relevant 
departments including Economic Research and Regional Cooperation Department on a research 
work. In particular, the selected DMCs mentioned in output 4 will be identified in close coordination 
with the regional departments by considering country partnership strategies or other relevant 
documents or bilateral consultations that endorse the needs and interest of the DMCs. Once the 
regional hub is operational, the regional hub secretariat will take over the implementation of the 
TA in close coordination with OAI and SDTC-GOV. 
 
17.  Arrangement on participation in the regional hub. Given the open and inclusive nature 
of the regional hub, all ADB DMCs are encouraged to participate in it. A formal agreement is, 
therefore, not required for DMCs to participate in the regional hub. Relevant development partners 
are invited to participate in the regional hub and related activities, including the use of the web 
portal mentioned in output 3. Initially, the participation of DMCs is on a voluntary basis and to be 
confirmed  by  a  follow-up  survey  for  DMCs.  The  TA  does  not  require  logistical support  or 
undertakings from the participating DMC governments. Arrangements may be amended in the 
medium to long term, given the discussions among DMCs, development partners, and ADB.

IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
22.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved (i) the 
Asian Development Bank (ADB) administering a portion of technical assistance not exceeding 
the equivalent of $500,000 to be financed on a grant basis by the Republic of Korea e-Asia and

Key Activities with Milestones 
1.  Regional hub on domestic resource mobilization and international tax cooperation established 
and institutionalized 
1.1 Establish secretariat function of the regional hub that is dedicated to coordinate among DMCs and 
development partners (Q1 2021–Q2 2021). 
1.2 Recruit consultants to manage the activities of the regional hub and form the secretariat (Q1 2021–Q2 
2021). 
1.3 Create and coordinate an ADB communication strategy to support country initiatives to disseminate the 
importance of strengthening DRM and ITC (Q1 2021–Q2 2021). 
1.4 Produce a generic template of communication strategy for DMCs to further tailor to their country-specific 
needs (Q1 2021–Q4 2021). 
1.5 Organize an MTRS workshop (Q2 2021). 
1.6 Review the workload of the secretariat annually and scale up the secretariat function as necessary (Q1 
2022–Q4 2023). 
2.   Strategic conferences and dialogues among developing member countries, development 
partners, and ADB facilitated 
2.1 Conduct strategic dialogues and policy-setting activities with development partners (Q2 2021–Q4 
2023). 
2.2 Organize the first high-level regional conference (Q2 2021–Q3 2021). 
2.3 Organize the second high-level regional conference (Q2 2022–Q3 2022). 
2.4 Organize the third high-level regional conference (Q2 2023–Q3 2023). 
3.    Web portal on the regional hub developed 
3.1 Create and make operational the initial web portal of the regional hub (Q1 2021–Q2 2021). 
4.   Digital solutions on domestic resource mobilization and international tax cooperation promoted 
4.1 Conduct needs assessments and develop recommendations on digital transformation in selected DMCs 
(Q3 2021–Q3 2023). 
4.2 Organize three capacity-building workshops on digital transformation of tax administrations (Q2 2021–
Q4 2023).
